chapter: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common type of cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation:
The most common type of cardiomyopathy is dilated cardiomyopathy. Restrictive cardiomyopathy 
is the least frequent. Cardiomyopathies are a heterogeneous group of diseases of the myocardium associated with 
mechanical and/or electrical dysfunction. They usually exhibit inappropriate ventricular 
hypertrophy or dilatation. The causes are frequently genetic. Cardiomyopathies maybe primary predominantly involving the heart or secondary to a systemic 
or multiorgan disorder. They occur in the absence of any coronary artery disease, valvular heart 
disease, congenital heart disease, or systemic arterial hypertension. Types of cardiomyopathy: • Dilated cardiomyopathy • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 723 
Sold by @itachibot • Restrictive cardiomyopathy • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy • Left ventricular non-compaction cardiomyopathy
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question: Question 2: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of:
questions.explanation:
Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy. Alcohol and its metabolites, especially acetaldehyde have a direct toxic effect on the myocardium 
which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy. Causes of dilated cardiomyopathy: • Acquired causes : • Infectious and non-infectious myocarditis: most common cause globally • Alcohol is the most common cause in India • Pregnancy: • Pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM) • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) • Stress-induced: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy • Drug-induced: • Doxorubicin (anthracycline) • Trastuzumab • Cyclophosphamide • Nutritional deficiency: • Beriberi (thiamine), • Keshan disease (selenium), • Carnitine deficiency • Endocrine: Hypo and hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, diabetes mellitus • Others: • Cobalt toxicity, • Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium) • Familial causes (50%): • Mutation in the cardiac myocyte titin gene • Haemochromatosis • Syndromes: Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Becker’s muscular dystrophy 724 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is the largest protein expressed in humans?
questions.explanation:
Titin is the largest protein expressed in humans. Titin is the third myofilament of cardiac muscle. It has a single giant polypeptide spanning from 
Z-disk to the M-band region of the sarcomere. Mutation in TTN, the gene encoding titin, is responsible for 20% of all cases of dilated 
cardiomyopathy.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 4: Two brothers were arguing over a property dispute when the elder of the two complained of 
chest pain and collapsed. He was taken to the hospital but was declared brought dead. The 
condition responsible for the death of the patient is grouped under which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of sudden cardiac death in a previously healthy man, under a stressful 
situation, is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or 
stress-induced cardiomyopathy. During extreme psychological stress, there is a catecholamine 
surge. This causes microcirculation spasms which lead to a transient myocardial stunning. It is 
usually seen in middle-aged women. It leads to left ventricular contractile dysfunction. The left ventricular apex is most often affected 
which leads to apical ballooning. This resembles a “takotsubo,” which is Japanese for “fishing pot 
for trapping octopus”. Histologically, acute cases may show microscopic areas of necrosis characterized by myocyte 
hyper contraction known as contraction band necrosis. Chronic cases may exhibit microscopic foci 
of granulation tissue. The first image below shows a ventriculogram showing takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The second 
image shows a 'takotsubo,' or octopus fishing pot. 725 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient is admitted to the hospital with heart failure due to dilated cardiomyopathy. 
Toxicity by which of the following does not cause this?
questions.explanation:
Selenium deficiency (Keshan's disease) is known to produce dilated cardiomyopathy and not its 
toxicity. Causes of dilated cardiomyopathy: Acquired causes: • Infectious and non-infectious myocarditis is the most common cause globally • Alcohol is the most common cause in India • Pregnancy: • Pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM) • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) • Stress-induced: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy • Drug-induced: • Doxorubicin: anthracyclines • Trastuzumab • Cyclophosphamide • Nutritional deficiency: • Beriberi (thiamine), • Keshan disease (selenium) • Carnitine deficiency • Endocrine: Hypo and hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, diabetes mellitus • Others: 726 
Sold by @itachibot • Cobalt toxicity • Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium) Familial causes (50%): • Mutation in the cardiac myocyte titin gene • Haemochromatosis • Syndromes: Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Becker’s muscular dystrophy
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 6: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains 
of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. 
Which type of cardiomyopathy is usually seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, liver microscopy shows hepatocellular iron, stained blue with Perl's 
Prussian blue stain. The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. Dilated 
cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the predominant type of cardiomyopathy seen in hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis can also produce restrictive cardiomyopathy, but it is less common than DCM. The image below shows hemochromatosis. There is hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl's 
Prussian blue.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 7: The histological examination of the heart of a patient who died due to heart failure is given 
below. What underlying condition did the patient most likely have?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the histology image shows ninja-star like nuclei in myocytes. This is 
suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). These are non-specific findings but the presence of  5% myocytes with ninja star-like nuclei are 
suggestive of DCM. Here, DCM is due to titin-truncating mutations. Truncating mutations are 
those which shorten the coding sequence of the genes. 727 
Sold by @itachibot Histologically they appear as variable myocyte hypertrophy and interstitial fibrosis. The nuclei are 
enlarged, bizarre and hyperchromatic exhibiting a ninja-star like appearance. The image given below explains the ninja star-like nuclei in the myocytes.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 8: A 14-year-old boy who collapsed while playing basketball was brought to the emergency room 
and was resuscitated. On evaluation, he was found to have sustained ventricular tachycardia 
secondary to arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy. Which syndrome is 
associated with this?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the patient suffered from sustained ventricular tachycardia secondary to 
arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC). ARVC is associated with Naxos 
syndrome. ARVC is autosomal dominant cardiomyopathy characterized by fibrofatty replacement in the 
myocardium of the ventricles. It most commonly affects the right ventricle. It is due to mutations 
in the gene encoding desmosome-associated protein plakophilin 2. This leads to defective 
cell-adhesion proteins in the desmosomes that link adjacent cardiac myocytes. As shown in the image below, Naxos syndrome is characterized by woolly hair and 
palmoplantar hyperkeratosis. 728 
Sold by @itachibot Morphology shows severe thinning of the right ventricular wall due to loss of myocytes, 
accompanied by extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis. The image given below is a gross photograph of the heart showing dilated right ventricle and near 
transmural replacement of its free wall with fat and fibrosis. Carvajal syndrome is a variant of Naxos disease but is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 9: 716 
Sold by @itachibot An autopsy was done for a young patient who had a sudden cardiac death. It revealed massive 
myocardial hypertrophy without ventricular dilation. The image obtained on microscopy is 
given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and autopsy findings are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 
(HCM). The image given is a histologic section of cardiac muscle showing myocyte disarray and 
extreme hypertrophy as seen in HCM. 729 
Sold by @itachibot HCM is the leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young adults. It is defined as left ventricular 
hypertrophy of >15mm on ECHO. The left ventricular myocardium is poorly compliant. This 
leads to abnormal diastolic filling and intermittent ventricular outflow obstruction, i.e., primarily 
diastolic dysfunction. The gross features of HCM are: • Massive myocardial hypertrophy usually without ventricular dilation • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy- disproportionate thickening of the ventricular septum relative 
to the left ventricle free wall • Banana-shaped left ventricle- due to bulging of the ventricular septum into the lumen The image given below shows changes in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy compared to a normal 
heart. HCM shows asymmetric septal hypertrophy and thickened left ventricle wall. Histologic features of the HCM are: • Massive myocyte hypertrophy- with transverse myocyte diameters frequently greater than 40 
m, normal is approximately 15 m. • Myofiber disarray- haphazard disarray of bundles of myocytes, individual myocytes, and 
contractile elements in sarcomeres within cells • Interstitial fibrosis and replacement fibrosis The image given below is a histologic section of cardiac muscle showing myocyte disarray and 
extreme hypertrophy seen in an abnormal HCM septum. 730 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 10: Mutations causing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are most commonly seen in the gene 
encoding which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Mutations causing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are most commonly seen in the genes encoding 
 -myosin heavy chain ( -MHC). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant disease. In the majority of cases 
it is due to missense mutations in the following two sarcolemmal protein genes: • Myosin binding protein C (MYBC) • Beta myosin heavy chain (MYH7)
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation:
Restrictive cardiomyopathy is caused by hemochromatosis, ergotamine, amyloidosis and carcinoid 
syndrome. Trastuzumab causes dilated cardiomyopathy. Restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM) is characterized by increased ventricular stiffness causing 
impaired diastolic filling of the ventricles. The stiffness is secondary to an underlying disease 
causing accumulation of intra and intercellular substances in the myocardium. Causes of RCM: • Infiltration disorders • Amyloidosis (most common) • Sarcoidosis • Storage disorders • Fabry’s disease • Glycogen storage disease (type II>> III) 731 
Sold by @itachibot • Hemochromatosis (DCM>RCM) • Fibrotic disorders • Scleroderma • Endomyocardial fibrosis • R-Radiation • E-Ergotamine • S-Serotonin • T-Tropical Endomyocardial fibrosis • C-Carcinoid syndrome • Miscellaneous: post open heart surgery, diabetes. Morphology of RCM: • Ventricles are of almost normal size or slightly enlarged • The myocardium is non-compliant • Biatrial dilation is commonly observed • Patchy or diffuse interstitial fibrosis
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 12: A 35-year-old female presents with progressive dyspnoea on exertion for one week along with 
a diffuse rash. Blood investigations are significant for an absolute eosinophil count of 4600 / 
mm³. Which of the following is caused by the patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the patient has progressive dyspnoea along with hypereosinophilia. This is 
suggestive of Loeffler's endocarditis. It leads to restrictive cardiomyopathy. There is peripheral eosinophilia and eosinophilic infiltrates in multiple organs, including the 
heart. Major basic protein (MBP) is a toxic product released from eosinophils. This initiates 
endomyocardial necrosis followed by scarring. It leads to endomyocardial fibrosis, typically with 
large mural thrombi. Many patients with Loeffler's endocarditis have a myeloproliferative disorder. This is associated 
with chromosomal rearrangements involving platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGF)- or 
- genes.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 13: A 2-year-old girl was brought to the outpatient department with complaints of difficulty in 
breathing and fatigue. The child had a history of intrauterine exposure to mumps. The cardiac 
evaluation showed a decrease in ventricular compliance. Which of the following would be the 
cause of the child's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
In this scenario, the decrease in ventricular compliance indicates restrictive 
cardiomyopathy. Endocardial fibroelastosis is an uncommon restrictive heart 
condition characterized by fibroelastic thickening that typically involves the left ventricular 
endocardium. It is most common in the first 2 years of life. It results from several different insults including 
viral infections (e.g., intrauterine exposure to mumps) or mutations in the gene for tafazzin. These 
mutations affect mitochondrial inner membrane integrity. 732 
Sold by @itachibot Endomyocardial fibrosis is a disease of children and young adults in Africa and other tropical 
areas. It is characterized by fibrosis of the ventricular endocardium and subendocardium that 
extends from the apex upward. The aetiology is unknown. Loeffler endomyocarditis results in endomyocardial fibrosis, typically with large mural thrombi. 
The overall morphology is similar to the tropical disease. In addition to the cardiac changes, there 
is often peripheral eosinophilia and eosinophilic infiltrates in multiple organs, including the heart.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question: Question 14: Myocarditis is most commonly caused by which of the following viral infections?
questions.explanation:
Viral infections are the most common cause of myocarditis. Coxsackie viruses A and B and other 
enteroviruses account for most of the cases. Myocarditis is a diverse group of pathologic entities in which infectious microorganisms and/or a 
primary inflammatory process cause myocardial injury.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 15: 718 
Sold by @itachibot Which serum protein is the major component of senile cardiac amyloid deposits?
questions.explanation:
Transthyretin is the major component of senile cardiac amyloid deposits. It is a normal serum 
protein synthesized in the liver that transports thyroxine and retinol-binding protein. Amyloidosis of the heart can develop as a consequence of systemic amyloidosis or it may be 
localized. This is particularly seen in the elderly (senile cardiac amyloidosis). It has a far better 
prognosis than systemic amyloidosis. Presentation of cardiac amyloidosis: • Restrictive cardiomyopathy- most common • Asymptomatic • Dilation • Arrhythmias • Ischemic disease • Valvular disease. The chambers are usually of normal size, but can be dilated and have thickened walls. Small, 
semitranslucent nodules resembling drips of wax may be seen on the atrial endocardial surface, 
particularly on the left. Histologically, hyaline eosinophilic deposits of amyloid are found in: • Interstitium • Conduction tissue • Valves, endocardium • Pericardium • Small intramural coronary arteries. 733 
Sold by @itachibot The image given shows an endomyocardial biopsy of a patient with cardiac amyloidosis stained as 
follows: A) Congo red only, B) Apple-green birefringence under polarized light
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 16: One week following a diagnosis of myocardial infarction, a patient experiences precordial 
pain and develops a fever of 101.5°F. Physical examination is remarkable for a loud friction 
rub. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario suggests post-myocardial infarction fibrinous pericarditis. It is the 
most common type of pericarditis. Clinically, there is a loud pericardial friction rub. There is a rubbery fibrin mass loosely glueing 
the parietal and visceral pericardium together (bread and butter). It may resolve or become 
organized to produce adhesive pericarditis. It is usually seen following: • Myocardial infarction • Rheumatic fever • Trauma • Uremia • Radiation • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) • Severe pneumonia Types of acute pericarditis: Serous pericarditis: There is a mild inflammation of epicardial and pericardial surfaces. Both 
acute and chronic inflammatory cells are present. There is exudative serous fluid, usually 50–200 
mL. Thus, it develops slowly and rarely alters cardiac function. It is caused by: • Rheumatic fever 734 
Sold by @itachibot • SLE • Systemic scleroderma • Tumours • Uremia • Viral infection • Tuberculosis Suppurative /purulent pericarditis: It may be due to bacterial, mycotic, or parasitic invasion. The 
inflammation may extend into the surrounding mediastinum. It usually, results in organization 
and, therefore, constrictive pericarditis with clinical sequelae. The entry of the pathogen into the 
pericardium may be by: • direct extension • seeding from blood • lymphatic spread • seeding by instrumentation Hemorrhagic pericarditis: It can be due to tuberculosis or a malignant neoplasm (from lung or 
breast). It can also be seen following cardiac surgery. Caseous pericarditis is almost always 
tubercular in origin.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 17: A 52-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction 4 weeks back, develops fever, 
pericardial chest pain and pericardial effusion. What is the aetiology behind the patient's 
present condition?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, fever, pericardial pain and effusion 4 weeks after MI, is suggestive of 
Dressler's syndrome. The aetiology of Dressler's syndrome is autoimmune. It is also known as post-myocardial infarction (post-MI) cardiac injury syndrome. It occurs one 
week to as long as two to three months after MI. A fibrinous or fibrinohemorrhagic pericarditis usually develops around the second or third 
day following a transmural infarct. It is a result of the underlying myocardial inflammation. Dressler's syndrome is believed to have an autoimmune aetiology. There is an inflammatory 
reaction to myocardial neo-antigens formed as a result of MI.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 18: The autopsy of a patient who died due to heart failure revealed concretio cordis. Which of the 
following is this condition associated with?
questions.explanation:
Concretio cordis occurs in advanced cases of constrictive pericarditis. In constrictive pericarditis, a thick,0.5 - 1cm, fibrous scar tissue is formed. This can obliterate the 
pericardial space and sometimes calcify. In extreme cases, it can resemble a plaster mold and is 
known as concretio cordis. Constrictive pericarditis may be idiopathic or can occur following: • Pericarditis- serous or caseous 735 
Sold by @itachibot • Cardiac surgery • Heavy irradiation Adhesive mediastinopericarditis occurs when adhesion and fibrosis extends from the parietal 
pericardium into the mediastinum Soldier’s plaque is a focal pearly thickened epicardial plaque. It indicative of healed pericarditis
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is the most common primary tumour of the adult heart?
questions.explanation:
Myxomas are the most common primary tumours of the heart in adults. 90% of myxomas are located in the atria. The left-to-right ratio of the myxoma is approximately 
4:1. The region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum is the favoured site of origin. Histopathological examination shows stellate or globular myxoma, “lepidic," cells. Peculiar 
vessel-like or gland-like structures are characteristic. Major clinical manifestations are fever and 
malaise (due to IL-6). Valvular “ball-valve” obstruction or embolization can occur. Important points on cardiac tumors: • Most common cardiac tumour: metastasis • Most common benign cardiac tumour: atrial myxoma • Most common primary cardiac tumour in adults: atrial myxoma • Most common primary cardiac tumour in children: rhabdomyoma The image given below shows an abundant amorphous extracellular matrix. It contains scattered 
multinucleate myxoma cells in various groupings, including abnormal vessel-like formations.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following conditions is commonly seen in patients with null mutations of the 
PRKAR1A gene?
questions.explanation:
736 
Sold by @itachibot Null mutations in the PRKAR1A gene is seen in Carney's complex. Cardiac myxomas are present 
in 30–40% of Carney complex patients. Familial syndromes associated with myxomas have activating mutations in the GNAS1 gene or 
null mutations in PRKAR1A. Mutations in GNAS1 is associated with McCune-Albright syndrome. 
PRKAR1A gene encodes a regulatory subunit of a cyclic-AMP-dependent protein kinase (Carney 
complex). Skin lesions are the most common manifestation of the Carney complex. The most common type 
of endocrine tumour in the Carney complex is the primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical 
disease (PPNAD). It is a form of bilateral adrenal hyperplasia that leads to adrenocorticotropic 
hormone (ACTH)-independent Cushing syndrome. NAME syndrome and LAMB syndrome are subsets of the Carney complex. The LAMB 
acronym refers to lentigines, atrial myxoma, and blue nevi. NAME refers to nevi, atrial myxoma, 
myxoid neurofibromas, and ephelids. Components of Carney Complex: • Skin pigmented lesions (lentigines, blue nevi, other) • Myxomas (cutaneous, mucosal, cardiac, other) • PPNAD (Cushing Syndrome) • GH-PRL-producing adenomas (acromegaly) • Leydig or Sertoli cell tumors • Ovarian cystadenoma or carcinoma • Thyroid adenoma or cancer • Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma • Breast ductal adenoma • Osteochondromyxoma • Cancers (liver, pancreas, adrenal) Carney triad: • Extra-adrenal paraganglioma • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor • Pulmonary chondroma Carney–Stratakis Syndrome: Familial paraganglioma and gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST)
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question: Question 21: What is the most common site of a cardiac myxoma?
questions.explanation:
Atrial myxomas most commonly occur in the left atrium. Myxoma is usually single, but can rarely be multiple. The region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial 
septum is the favoured site of origin. Mobile tumours exert a “wrecking-ball” effect, causing 
damage to the valve leaflets. 737 
Sold by @itachibot They can be sporadic or familial. The image given below shows a gross picture of an atrial cardiac myxoma arising from the region 
of the fossa ovalis and extending to mitral valve orifice: Sporadic Type Myxoma

questions.question:
Question 22: The histopathologic findings seen in a resected heart mass is given below. What is the 
diagnosis? 720 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given histological slide shows abundant spider cells. They are seen in rhabdomyoma. Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Routine histologic 
processing often artifactually reduces the abundant cytoplasm to thin strands that stretch from 
the nucleus to the surface membrane. This appearance is referred to as “spider” cells. Rhabdomyoma is the most frequent primary tumour of the pediatric heart. 50% of cases are 
associated with tuberous sclerosis, with mutations in the tumour-suppressor genes TSC1 and 
TSC2. They are usually multiple and occur in ventricles preferentially. They often regress 
spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas. Image given shows spider cell in rhabdomyoma: 738 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question: Question 23: The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is
questions.explanation:
The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft 
arteriopathy. Complications following cardiac transplantation: Allograft rejection: It is the primary concern that requires close surveillance. Both classic cellular 
rejection and antibody-mediated rejection is recognized. Cellular rejection is characterized by 
interstitial lymphocytic inflammation, with associated myocyte damage. Allograft arteriopathy: It is the single most important long-term limitation for cardiac 
transplantation. It is a late, progressive, diffusely stenosing intimal proliferation in the coronary 
arteries, leading to ischemic injury. It can lead to silent myocardial infarction since transplant 
patients have denervated hearts and do not experience angina. Progressive congestive heart 
failure and sudden cardiac death can also occur. Other postoperative problems include infection and malignancies, especially Epstein–Barr 
virus-associated B-cell lymphomas. The image given below shows allograft arteriopathy. There is severe diffuse concentric intimal 
thickening producing critical stenosis. The internal elastic lamina and media are intact (Movat 
pentachrome stain, elastin black) 739 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 24: What is the most common cause of the condition shown in the given image? 721 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows a heart with left ventricular hypertrophy. The most common cause of left 
ventricular hypertrophy is chronic hypertension.
questions.chapter_heading: Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac

questions.question:
Question 25: Which of the following patients with cardiac hypertrophy will have an associated increase in 
capillary density?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, a marathon runner will have cardiac hypertrophy with increased capillary 
density. Aerobic exercise, e.g., long-distance running, is associated with volume-load 
hypertrophy accompanied by an increase in capillary density. This is not seen in other forms of 
hypertrophy. This decreases resting heart rate and blood pressure. In hypertrophy due to pressure or volume overload, there is a sustained increase in mechanical 
work. This cause myocytes to increase in size thus increasing the size and weight of the heart. The 
hypertrophied heart has an increased oxygen consumption but decreased supply. This is because 
hypertrophy is not accompanied by a proportional increase in capillary numbers. This leads to 
ischemia-related decompensation, which can evolve to cardiac failure and eventually lead to 
death. The causes and consequences of hypertrophy are summarized in the below image. 740 
Sold by @itachibot Heart weight, rather than wall thickness, is the best measure of hypertrophy in dilated hearts. A patient with systemic hypertension has pressure-overload hypertrophy. A patient with an echo finding of an aortic valvular area of 0.6cm² is suggestive of aortic stenosis. 
There is pressure-overload hypertrophy. A patient with a high pitched holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex is suggestive of mitral 
regurgitation. There is volume-overload hypertrophy. 741 
Sold by @itachibot Congenital and Valvular Heart Disease
